overall_summary: The reasoning trajectory demonstrates a methodical approach to forecasting hourly transformer load data with clear daily seasonality. It addresses data limitations (only 4 days of historical data) by selecting a simple yet effective averaging technique. The analysis carefully considers day-of-week effects, data completeness, and rounding precision while acknowledging the inability to model weekly patterns due to insufficient data.
common_data_patterns: Day-night pattern (negative values during daytime, positive at night)
No missing values in historical data
Insufficient data for weekly pattern detection
key_insights: Use of same-hour averages across multiple days to handle daily seasonality
Explicit handling of day-of-week mismatches between historical and forecast periods
Rounding forecasts to 3 decimals to match input data precision
Rejection of complex models (e.g., Exponential Smoothing) due to limited historical records
Repetition of daily pattern for multi-day forecasts when lacking day-specific data
complexity_analysis: Moderately complex: Combines heuristic analysis of data patterns with practical implementation trade-offs. Balances statistical considerations (seasonality, averaging) with data constraints, but avoids advanced modeling due to limited dataset.
